citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
**NO ANIMALS ON THE PREMISES AT THE TIME OF THE INSPECTION
**During a review of records, it was noted that there were several deviations with post-surgical monitoring and care of the
animals in Protocol 21-18. Seizures were listed in the protocol as endpoint criteria; however, Pig #1 was recorded as
having experienced seizures on August 12th and 13th with no recorded interventions. Pig #1 was noted as having
experienced a grand mal seizure at 7:45 am on August 13th, at which time the veterinary staff notified the team, however,
the team didn't respond until 8:15am and while they were on the way, however, the pig died at 8:20am without having
received any treatment. Pig #2 was noted as having a binder clip used to attach the I.V. line to the ear when the surgeon
experienced difficulty in suturing the I.V line to the ear. The animal care staff involved in the surgeries were listed as "in
training" not having completed the required training disqualifying them from participating in the surgeries. Procedures
involving animals should be conducted in a manner that is in accordance with the proposed activities reviewed by the
IACUC to ensure the animals will not undergo unnecessary pain or distress. It is the responsibility of the IAUCUC to
ensure the principal investigator adheres to the proposed activities related to the care and use of the animals that have
been reviewed and approved by the IACUC avoid or minimize any unnecessary discomfort, pain and/or distress.
The IACUC has investigated the incident and implemented procedures to prevent future occurrences.
**Corrected prior to the inspection

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.
citations.narrative:
During a review of records, it was noted that related Protocol #21-18, two syringes of propofol were labelled
inappropriately with no indication of formulation or expiration date. Medications, anesthesia and analgesia to be utilized
during animal procedures should be appropriately labelled in order to provide adequate veterinary medical care. It is the
responsibility of the IACUC to ensure activities involving animals are performed in a manner that provides appropriate pre
and post procedural care according to established veterinary medical and nursing procedures.
**Corrected prior to the inspection
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
